en_second_half: Jake introduced me to West; now Jake will be my sole remaining connection to West. The thought makes me a little sad, but then I remember I have the couch and T-virus zombies waiting for me inside.

en_second_half: damn, I really wish I’d seen it more. “Bye, Anna.”

en_second_half: ask me for help. I sit up, too, tucking a loose strand of hair behind my ear. Focus, Anna.

en_first_half: It’s surreal to be here with her after all this time. I was so close to being done with this, so near to the finish line, yet here I am, having to improvise an intricate plan B at the eleventh hour with a Muppet in human form as my co-conspirator. Don’t get me wrong, beneath the baked, unshowered disarray, Anna is still a beautiful woman, with enormous brown eyes, creamy skin, and long, willowy limbs. I’d always been fascinated with the perfect beauty mark just above her lip. Unfortunately, right now she looks like
en_second_half: she’s fallen out of a tree and crawled through a field of tangly briers to get back to her apartment. This is probably the closest I’ve ever seen to her natural hair color because the pink has grown out a good inch, leaving a stripe of brown at her roots. Her makeup is, I presume, from yesterday; shadows of mascara carve dark circles beneath her eyes. Despite the old makeup and frazzled appearance, there’s still something striking about her. Her eyes are enormous and bright, framed with dark lashes, her steady gaze entirely without artifice.

en_first_half: Though I am nearly certain her mind has wandered to something other than the topic at hand, I let her stare at the wall
en_second_half: a little longer so I can stare at her and reconcile this version of Anna with the one I lived with for two years.

en_first_half: As roommates, we didn’t know each other well—that much is probably obvious—but there is an intimacy to sharing a space with someone, a certain kind of kinship that comes with daily proximity. Anna was reasonably tidy and paid her half of the rent when it was due, but she’d never struck me as the organized, driven, premed type. The one time we talked about it, she
en_second_half: said something about medicine being the most palatable of the “real job” options, but she seemed overwhelmed a lot, studying late into the night and painting to decompress in what little free time she had. That she ultimately switched her major to fine art makes a certain amount of sense, but I want to punch myself for not realizing she wasn’t studying medicine at all anymore.

en_second_half: as far from this dark, cramped living room as I can imagine. Right now, I need Anna to believe she can do this. Yes, she may be at rock bottom, but I need her to think she is just one fairy godmother moment away from sliding gracefully into the world she’s imagining.

en_second_half: yellow sundress. I have to assume she has an extremely deft plastic surgeon, because she somehow looks like a twenty-five-year-old sixty-year-old.

en_first_half: “Anna,” he says finally, very gently. “The truth is, you could just smile on my arm and be okay. I promise
en_second_half: I’m not trying to leave you unprepared. The sad reality is that my parents are unlikely to pay you much attention regardless.”

en_first_half: I walk back inside, realizing I’d been so focused on the sleeping situation, I haven’t properly flailed over the sheer bliss that is our bungalow. In fact, I’m pretty sure the only thing in here I could afford is the roll of eco-friendly toilet paper I can clearly see from where I stand. And even that looks pretty fancy. There’s a real Isle Esme feel to the decor (if you know, you know), with carved bamboo, recycled teak, jellyfish light fixtures, and a massive canopy bed. Wide windows and the open entrance
en_second_half: bring the outside in and allow me to glance over at West, who seems to be mid–mental spiral, managing to look even more morose than he did thirty seconds ago. Isle Esme vibes or not, there will be no headboard breaking here. Near one wall is a chest with our names stamped into the top, a pair of towels folded to look like stingrays, and a jar of chocolate chip cookies that are probably made with the world’s most expensive chocolate but hey, Gede did say it was all-inclusive. I help myself.

en_first_half: I have a lot of faults. I drink milk from the carton, I never make my bed, I am slothful, and sometimes I’ll just set the new roll of toilet paper on top of the empty roll instead of changing it. A monster. I am also gluttonous: I don’t want a few peanut M&M’s; I want the entire bag. Why have one
en_second_half: margarita when three is such a nice, satisfying number? Everyone knows why! And that’s why I go back for seconds right now. But karma is Team West: his eyes open just as I glance again. They widen and he reaches down to cup his Goddamn before he turns, facing away. “Anna,” he says, his voice spluttering in the water’s spray. “Are you peeking?”

en_first_half: He was right. Focus was always a challenge, and apparently it didn’t end with baseball. I came here with the knowledge that all I need to do is limp this lie to September, and I can finally exhale, but we’re less than an hour into this farce and I’m already off track:
en_second_half: I peeked, and it was a huge mistake. It’s not that I didn’t know Anna was attractive all those years ago; it’s that we barely saw each other, and I was so driven to finish my degree and never have to work for my father again that Anna—attractive or not—was easy to overlook.

en_second_half: clever but humble. I want to know that version of him and worry he will forever be frozen in this caricature of the irresponsible youngest son as long as he works for Weston’s.

en_second_half: from behind it. The diamond on her ring flashes in the flickering light. “That surprised me.”

en_second_half: hands me one before lifting his own. “Well, whatever. To the final few months: if you pull this off, you’re free.”

en_second_half: laser focus to me. “How do your professors react to your hair?”

en_first_half: “And what’s the deal with Alex? Based on the way you talked about him on the plane, I expected you
en_second_half: two to jovially poke at each other, but that was like dragging a proverbial sword through each other with your eyeballs.”

en_first_half: “Well, mostly because he’s an asshole. But also, kids growing up in a normal family get to be themselves, whoever that may be. But in families like
en_second_half: ours, one where everything basically revolves around keeping a single person happy—my dad—everybody has a role. My therapist used to refer to Alex as a flying monkey.”

en_second_half: shit just to turn us all in, then sit back and look like the good guy. He’s never grown out of it.”

en_second_half: leg over my hip, send an arm over my torso, and press her face to my neck. It took monumental focus to not go hard against her inner thigh, and because of it, I’d slept like absolute shit.

en_second_half: Slept in. By both of us. I squeeze my eyes shut against the reminder.

en_first_half: I sigh. I know she’s right but I’m already sleep-deprived and functioning on less than full brain power today.
en_second_half: I’m not sure I’m capable of dealing with both my family and Anna in this suit after last night. “Fine.”

en_first_half: “Oh!” Anna jerks a hand over her eyes. “Your Goddamn! Right there!” She turns away. “Sorry! I just—spaced
en_second_half: out—on your—God. And you’re not even harrrrrrr—Fuck me.” She coughs. “Okay. I’ll just meet you down at the restaurant.”

en_first_half: I can feel Anna’s eyes on the side of my face. This is how it always starts with Alex, and whatever suspicion he has about my marriage will only make it
en_second_half: worse. I know it’s irrational and a remnant of how we used to one-up each other for our dad’s approval when we were kids, but I want to beat him. At everything.

en_first_half: Anna slams the brakes on this line of thinking by putting an arm around my back, resting the other hand on my stomach
en_second_half: and gently scratching, just like she unconsciously did last night. I work to suppress a shiver. Turning, she looks at him over her shoulder.

en_first_half: Eko goes through the basics of paddling, giving us tips about what areas of the
en_second_half: reef to avoid as we approach. “Is everyone comfortable with the basics of kayaking?” she asks.

en_first_half: I reach back, pulling my T-shirt up and off, tossing it to the side. Alex hesitates and
en_second_half: then does the same, his expression turning homicidal when I smirk down at his soft little paunch.

en_first_half: Alex snorts, looking at her derisively, like she’s an idiot. In a hot
en_second_half: flush, my hackles are up, and every rational thought goes out the window.

en_first_half: “Course you are, sweetheart,” I say, steadying my voice and looking down at Anna.
en_second_half: “I went running without you this morning and you really let me have it.”

en_first_half: “We work out together every morning.” I’m speaking to Alex but holding Anna’s gaze. Maybe it’s the pent-up frustration from last night, or maybe my brother just
en_second_half: brings out the worst in me and the best way to drag him is through his wife’s dissatisfaction, but I keep going. “Gets the blood flowing, doesn’t it?”

en_first_half: And that much is immediately apparent. She trips as she tries to climb in. I hold the boat steady for her, but she still ends up getting
en_second_half: in backward and then having to awkwardly turn around in the tiny space. I pretend to scratch my shoulder with my chin, glancing behind us. Fuck. Alex noticed.

en_first_half: Just then, Anna looks over and lets out a high-pitched shriek. “West! A sea turtle!” She
en_second_half: leans to the side, and her oar slides off her lap and into the clear water.

en_first_half: “He and I have never been close,” I say quickly, suddenly and deeply uninterested in spending the morning anywhere but right
en_second_half: here with Anna. “I think from the moment he was born, the only thing he cared about was impressing our father.”

en_first_half: “You drive Alex crazy because he can’t ever beat you even though he’s the older
en_second_half: brother. He’s probably jealous because you’re tall and hot and smart and he’s short and—”

en_first_half: Anna pulls her hand from the water and sends it absently down her stomach, leaving a trail of water that quickly pulls
en_second_half: into droplets and evaporates in the heat. “Is it weird that we lived together for two years and you don’t remember this?”

en_first_half: Gingerly, Anna lifts the ice, gasping at the small wound there.
en_second_half: She sets the ice back down, flushed, and nods decisively. “You’ll live.”

en_first_half: Anna scowls at him, and with the circle of people watching, crouches down, setting
en_second_half: two fingers on his leg. She immediately jerks her arm back. “Wow, it’s hot.”

en_first_half: Anna laughs. “Well, technically the twelfth, but the fifth was when he wrote me a song and got on his knees to
en_second_half: sing it to me, so that’s the night I see as our actual marriage.” She looks up at me, eyes soft. “He cried.”

en_first_half: I’m out of town but will make sure my roommate is there to
en_second_half: meet the courier. This is so exciting! The price sounds perfect. Thank you, Mel!

en_first_half: But because this is a Weston Party™, it doesn’t end there. Clustered down the center of each table are vases bursting with white orchids and sprays of spiky green palms. The plates are bone china, and they look old, rich old, vintage, with
en_second_half: about seventeen matching smaller plates and crystal champagne flutes at each place setting. I wonder idly if Janet had these brought over from her own collection, and then I realize she’d be more likely to just buy an entirely new set of priceless china.

en_first_half: “So how’s it going with your dad?” I say, standing and stretching. West was pretty shaken up after Ray
en_second_half: blindsided him in front of the Forbes editor. I can’t imagine what it’s like wanting to avoid your own father.

en_first_half: “What I don’t understand is why he has such a boner for you being CEO when
en_second_half: you clearly don’t want the job. Let him give it to Alex. He clearly wants it.”

en_first_half: “I’m not saying, but maybe I’m sort of saying, that there is one person
en_second_half: in this bungalow who could absolutely use a massage and his name isn’t Anna Green.”

en_first_half: Janet unfolds herself from her chair, floating like a vampire across to me, where she delivers a
en_second_half: kiss to the air on either side of my face. “Hello, darling. Nice of you to come.”

en_first_half: Reagan laughs down at her sand drawing. “Five more days,” she
en_second_half: says. “I’m having fun but I miss my dog and my friends.”

en_first_half: He blinks away, aiming a wry laugh down at the sand before he looks back up again.
en_second_half: “Shots fired, okay.” He looks over at Reagan. “Then would my niece like to dance with me?”

en_first_half: “Should we go?” she asks, setting her hand over mine on her chest.
en_second_half: “This feels like the start of something we don’t want Ray to see.”

en_first_half: “I was only fifteen when Grandpa died. We were all at the reading of the will, but you can imagine in a situation like that, especially for kids, a lot of the details sort of go over your head. The reading took hours. I understood,
en_second_half: basically, that he was leaving us each a very large sum of money. I understood that it was contingent on us being married. At the time, it didn’t seem so weird that he would want that. Kids sort of take those adult directives as law.”

en_first_half: “Really.” I turn my face to the sun and feel its warmth spread through me. Residual panic drains away and I feel only contentment. I have money from West, I have the
en_second_half: start of a potential—maybe, let’s hope—career as an artist. I might be falling in… I cut the thought off. “Mel just called me. Tell Dad I can cover it, absolutely no problem.”

en_first_half: The sound of a fork dropping onto porcelain breaks through my trance, and I blink over
en_second_half: to where Ray is now impatiently wiping his mouth on a napkin. “They just canceled now?”
